answers.answer: The currently accepted range for "normal" TSH is 0.3-3.0. Old ranges still persist, however, as many labs and doctors have not adopted the new range.  We, on this forum, use 0.3-3.0.  So, your TSH is high, which indicates that you might be hypothyroid.  However, TSH is the least important of the thyroid tests.  Your 6.72 indicates that you should have further testing.  You should have free T3, free T4 and TSH repeated on the same blood draw. If the free's support your TSH, that would be enough information to start you on meds and point you toward any further testing that ought to be done.  Make sure to get free T3 and T4, not total T3 and T4, which are considered antiquated tests.There are no OTC drugs that will bring TSH down.TSH, per se, has no association with diabetes.  However, if you are hypothyroid, then your whole metabolism slows down.  This can cause any number of problems in all systems of the body.Do you have hypo symptoms?  Google hypothyroid symptoms for a list.Can't comment on the iron, except to say that a great way to lower the iron level in your blood is to give blood.

Thank you for your advice and information. Most helpful and I am making an appointment to see a physician. With the amout I am working out and excercising with no results it is no wonder I feel sluggish and not getting any tone lately. Thank you again.

question: I recently attended a Health Fair here in Colorado and had my blood anylized. This covered cells and blood work. I just got my tests back and my Iron Serum wich should be between 45-200 MCG/DL came back 212The other was my TSH 3rd Generation levels which should be between 0.40 - 4.50 MUI/L and came back 6.72Is there any over the counter drugs I can take to bring these level back down? Should I be concened at such high levels? I have a family history of Diabetes. Does TSH have any association to Diabetes?
title: TSH Levels too high
